issue.title: don't group exported and unexported methods of an interface together
issue.body:
Version: `v0.2.0`.

Before:

```go
type I interface {
	A()
	B()

	c()
}
```

After:

```go
type I interface {
	A()
	B()
	c()
}
```

Perhaps `c` shouldn't be grouped together with `A` and `B`, since it is unexported?

In the real code that inspired this issue, the `c` is a “marker method” for members of the “sum type” `I`, while `A` and `B` are methods that return data common to the members of the “sum type”.

<sup>(I have filed this in the `unused` repo at first.  Apologies for the noise once again.)</sup>

body:
See the discussion in https://github.com/mvdan/gofumpt/issues/85. The premise is that this kind of grouping is very common in structs, but not nearly as common in interfaces. I think the vast majority of interfaces fall in one of two categories:

1) They are intended for external use, and each method is documented. gofumpt will not remove newlines between interface methods if either method has a godoc comment.
2) They do not have any comments, they are "flat", akin to a multi-line slice or map literal.

So my suggestion would be that, if you want to keep a logical separation between methods, you could document the methods themselves, or you could add a separation comment to clarify the grouping - then gofumpt shouldn't join the lines:

```
type i1 interface {
	DoA()
	DoB()

	// Undo methods below this point.
	
	UndoA()
	UndoB()
}
```

Maybe this rationale is flawed, I'm not sure. I'm open to ideas. cc @flimzy @Zamiell @ainar-g @Oiyoo

I slightly lean towards removing the feature entirely; its value add feels rather small, and it seems relatively prone to fighting the user when they are using empty lines as logical separators in reasonable ways.

We don't remove empty lines inside slice or map literals, for example, and I don't think we should start doing so either.

@mvdan, in my projects, I've basically moved to documenting every exported and unexported method.  That was for reasons unrelated to `gofumpt`, but it does give me the additional freedom to (not) group the methods however I want, so the removal of the feature wouldn't bother me too much.
I think #85 was known guess work. If we've proven our guess about grouping interfaces was wrong, it's not unreasonable to revert that change.
I'll let this sit for a week, in case there are any objections. If there are none, I think I'll remove the feature. Thanks all for the input so far :)

issue.title: Can no longer group interface members
README: use a simpler interface example

body: Thanks for fixing this! Is it going to be released as 0.2.2?
I intend to release v0.3.0 by tomorrow, to be included in gopls v0.8.0 hopefully.
